H0.text: Osmosis is the direction of water movement that solutes affect, which is why solute potential is also called osmotic potential.

H1.text: Permeability is the direction that solutes affect, which is why solute potential is also called osmotic potential.

H2.text: Electrolysis is the direction that solutes affect, which is why solute potential is also called osmotic potential.

A3.text: Osmotic pressure is a colligative property, meaning that the property depends on the concentration of the solute, but not on its content or chemical identity.

A4.text: Osmosis is the spontaneous net movement of solvent molecules through a selectively permeable membrane from a region of high water potential (region of lower solute concentration) to a region of low water potential (region of higher solute concentration), in the direction that tends to equalize the solute concentrations on the two sides.
